sn4.21:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near Silāvatī.
sn4.21:1.3: Now at that time several mendicants were meditating not far from the Buddha, diligent, keen, and resolute.
sn4.21:1.4: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of a brahmin with a large matted dreadlock, wearing an antelope hide. He was old, bent double, wheezing, and held a staff made of cluster fig tree wood. He went up to those mendicants and said,
sn4.21:1.5: “You’ve gone forth while young, reverends. You’re black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life, and you’ve never flirted with sensual pleasures.
sn4.21:1.7: Don’t give up what is visible in the present to chase after what takes effect over time.”
sn4.21:1.9: We’re giving up what takes effect over time to chase after what is visible in the present.
sn4.21:1.10: For the Buddha says that sensual pleasures take effect over time; they give much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.
sn4.21:1.11: But this teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”
sn4.21:1.12: When they had spoken, Māra the Wicked shook his head, waggled his tongue, raised his eyebrows until his brow puckered in three furrows, and departed leaning on his staff.
sn4.21:2.1: Then those senior mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said,
sn4.21:3.2: That was Māra the Wicked who came to pull the wool over your eyes!”
sn4.21:3.3: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha recited this verse:
sn4.21:4.1: “When a person has seen where suffering comes from
sn4.21:4.2: how could they incline towards sensual pleasures?
sn4.21:4.3: Realizing that attachment is a chain in the world,
sn4.21:4.4: a person would train to remove it.”
